texts.definition: The space containing game elements carried by diegetic characters.
markups: <style="Definition">The space containing game elements carried by diegetic characters.</style>

There is often a need to support functionality for managing items in games where players control characters that can carry several of these. <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> prove a solution to this by letting players examine, discard, upgrade, repair, and in other ways through a separate representation that the main game world.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Roleplaying%20Games">Roleplaying Games</link></style> grew out of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Miniature%20Games">Miniature Games</link></style> by focusing on individual characters, including their equipment. This lead many such games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20and%20Dragons">Dungeons and Dragons</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mutant">Mutant</link></style>, to have <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> and rules for how much the players' characters could carry (although these were often ignored).

This was carried on both in text-based computer versions (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Kingdoms">Kingdoms</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zork%20series">Zork series</link></style>), "character"-based ones (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Nethack">Nethack</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Slaves%20to%20Armok%20II:%20Dwarf%20Fortress">Slaves to Armok II: Dwarf Fortress</link></style>), and graphical ones (e.g. the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Elder%20Scrolls%20series">Elder Scrolls</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>). <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> make use of a common <style="CurrentLink">Inventory</style> between the player's character and his or her companions.

<style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> can also be found in other type of computer games, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maniac%20Mansion">Maniac Mansion</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Torchlight">Torchlight</link></style>. The storage areas available to players in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/FarmVille">FarmVille</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style> can be seen as <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> also.

The typical design of <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> consist of deciding how to provide functionality for how the <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> carried by <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> (or <style="Link"><link="parties">Parties</link></style>) can be interacted with. The most common characteristic of <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> is to limit the number of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that can be stored in them, effectively creating <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style>.

While probably the most common ''action'' available through <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> is that of dropping <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> from them, many games provide other functionality where selecting which <style="Link"><link="equipment">Equipment</link></style> to outfit oneself with is common - often through <style="Link"><link="equipment-slots">Equipment Slots</link></style>. The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout series</link></style> provides ways of negating the effects of <style="Link"><link="deterioration">Deterioration</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> supports <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style>. While it may be natural to consider <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> available to players those of their <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> it may also be that they can access the <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> of other <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="non-player-characters">Non-Player Characters</link></style>. This since <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> provide the basic functionality on which many actions that enable <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> rely on, e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Stealing">Stealing</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="trading">Trading</link></style>.

A case where it may not be possible to drop <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> from <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> is when these represent <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> rather than <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> (the two types may be mixed). This is typically combined with <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> that cease to be <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> and become pure <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> when retrieved. In this case, <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> can be seen as a way of modulating <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> since they provide ways of affecting the <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> available, but when the <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style> maintain their identities as <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> after being retrieved <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> can instead be seen as modulating the <style="Link"><link="pick-ups">Pick-Ups</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="resources">Resources</link></style> that are also <style="Link"><link="non-localized-resources">Non-Localized Resources</link></style> can be given their own areas (so they do not compete with other <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>) within <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style>.

<style="Link"><link="free-gift-inventories">Free Gift Inventories</link></style> are a special case of <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> which contain <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> that players can give to other players but not to themselves. They are typically present in games (e.g. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/CityVille">CityVille</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Zombie%20Lane">Zombie Lane</link></style>) on social media platforms, primarily Facebook.

<style="Link"><link="sockets">Sockets</link></style> have similarities with <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style>, and may in some cases be a feasible alternative to <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> does a combination of <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> and <style="Link"><link="sockets">Sockets</link></style> by having a common <style="CurrentLink">Inventory</style> for the <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Character</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="companions">Companions</link></style> but <style="Link"><link="sockets">Sockets</link></style> for the <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> actually equipped by them.

<style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> are often instantiated as <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, e.g. in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/NetHack">NetHack</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%20series">Fallout</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20series">Dragon Age series</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> combines this with functionality for exchanging <style="Link"><link="transferable-items">Transferable Items</link></style> while <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> provides support for <style="Link"><link="crafting">Crafting</link></style> in its <style="CurrentLink">Inventory</style>. Both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Fallout%203">Fallout 3</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dragon%20Age%20II">Dragon Age II</link></style> use their <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> to let players install <style="Link"><link="upgrades">Upgrades</link></style>. It is quite common to begin <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> when these kinds of <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> are entered, although this can break <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Minecraft">Minecraft</link></style> is an example of a game which does ''not'' do this).

However, <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> can be shown in other ways. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> often make the <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> part of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Character%20Sheets">Character Sheets</link></style> while games with <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Illocutionary%20Interfaces">Illocutionary Interfaces</link></style>, which are typically text-based, do it as part of the main interface.

<style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> are a way to modulate both <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, often to introduce <style="Link"><link="resource-caps">Resource Caps</link></style> by limited how many of the latter the former can carry. Since <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> that have <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> in their <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> are control of those items, the pattern instantiates <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Ownership">Ownership</link></style>. Having to manipulate the items in <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> can become <style="Link"><link="excise">Excise</link></style> to players.

While <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> may support <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> in that one can carry <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style>, it may also conflict with a <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> simply because they represent <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> differently than in the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or that they allow unrealistic amounts of <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> to be carried. This issue is significantly magnified if entering <style="CurrentLink">Inventory</style> game modes through <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> that invoke <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> and provide interface elements with <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>. The use of <style="CurrentLink">Inventories</style> does however often help maintain <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> while making gameplay smooth since it can allow quick access to <style="Link"><link="game-items">Game Items</link></style> not in public sight.
